publicationStmt.publisher: The Characters that shaped the Silk Road - A Database and Digital Paleography of Tarim

history.provenance: found in Unknownduring T II S 53

seg.seg: he did not transgress moral behaviour

p.note: This fragment, initially wrongly classified as Old Uyghur with the press mark U 6905a, was identified as a Sanskrit fragment with TB glosses by Dieter Maue. Klaus Wille, whose readings I thankfully quote here, subsequently identified it as a fragment of Aśvaghoṣa's Buddhacarita (Michaël Peyrot).
swaromñesa (perl.sg.) is a late form for class. swarauñesa.

snai miyäṣñe is a late form for snai miyäṣṣälñe. As for the remnant of another gloss to the left, -tse is a frequent adjective suffix and the restoration of this second gloss is uncertain (Dieter Maue, p.c.).

snai miyäṣñe glosses Skt. Bc.2.9c nirāmayaṃ 'free of disease'. A further gloss ending in ///tse is found to the left, perhaps glossing Skt. Bc.2.9c caiva 'and just' or otherwise the preceding sukhaṃ 'ease' (Dieter Maue, p.c.). tanmaṣ(ṣar) glosses Skt. Bc.2.9d praj(a)jñ(ire) 'gave birth'. This gloss and the relevant Sanskrit text are flipped over to the verso of the fragment. The last akṣara-like symbol under jñ(i), a little bit to the right, belongs to a gloss to the original text of the verso, not this one (see line lānt wat). The gloss is written in black ink, apparently on an earlier gloss in fainter ink, perhaps originally the same word. The beginning of the gloss is clear and it is certainly a form of tǝnmǝsk-caus. 'generate; give birth', but it is not fully clear whether the last akṣara is completely abraded or has simply been left out. Since there may be a long descender going down to the right of [d]ā in the next line (), the correct reading may be tanma[ṣ](ṣa)[r](\).

The possibly correct reading tanma[ṣ](ṣa)[r](\) would stand for a 3pl.pt. tanmäṣṣare* with the shorter ending -r (which, as should be noted however, is not in any way regular, not even in the late language (133-4) and a for ä in the second syllable. Otherwise, a 3pl.pt.mid. tanmaṣ(ṣa)〈nte〉 would also be a possibility, in view of the fact that this verb is both active and middle (753).

For ram 'like' (class. ramt), which normally renders Skt. iva, there is no direct correlate in the Sanskrit text. It is probably a second rendering of vā 'or' in its meaning 'like, as' (: IV, 88). Thus, vā was glossed two times: once as wat 'or' and once as ram 'like'. In the second element , tsere is a 3pl.prt.mid.; the Sanskrit equivalent is a 3du.pf.

lānt wat ram glosses Skt. Bc.2.13c p(a)t(iṃ) v(ā) 'or the lord'. Due to a piece flipped over from the recto, I could not read this gloss fully in my previous study (167). The present reading was made possible by a restoration of the fragment. The second element , mā tsere, glosses Skt. Bc.2.13d na vyabhiceratur 'they did not offend; they did not transgress against'. Before the restoration of the fragment, this gloss was not visible at all.

glosses Skt. Bc.2.14c n(a) cacār(a dharmaṃ) '[none] practised religion' (II, 22). Faint lines under this gloss blur the reading. The akṣara following [t]ka is illegible and seems to have been wiped out intentionally. In my previous study (167), I had read mā śa[t]ka – pap[āṣṣ]· /// = mā śatka papāṣṣ(orñe). Thanks to the restoration of the fragment, the reading could be slightly improved. In any case, if the reading is correct (my interpretation requires that the grey spot found here was not intended to be part of the gloss), the gloss appears to be the reverse of the Sanskrit text: in the Sanskrit text, the law is not practised; in the Tocharian gloss, the law is not violated.

list.item: I changed sunsequently to subsequently in the remarks, added the images, added the link to IDP, untangled the line numbers, added the link from papāṣo(rñ)e to papāṣṣorñe. –Martin (Sat, 2018-09-29, 04:24:28 (CEST))

This fragment, initially wrongly classified as Old Uyghur with the press mark U 6905a, was identified as a Sanskrit fragment with TB glosses by Dieter Maue. Klaus Wille, whose readings I thankfully quote here, subsequently identified it as a fragment of Aśvaghoṣa's Buddhacarita (Michaël Peyrot).
a1x swaromñesa a2x /// -tse a2y snai miyäṣñe a2z tanmaṣ(ṣar) b1x lānt wat ram b1y mā tsere /// b2x mā śatka papāṣṣorñe|papāṣo(rñ)e ///
a1x in swetness a2x ... a2y without damage a2z gave birth b1x or like the king b1y they did not trick/deceive b2x he did not transgress moral behaviour

a1x. swaromñesa (perl.sg.) is a late form for class. swarauñesa.

a2y. snai miyäṣñe is a late form for snai miyäṣṣälñe. As for the remnant of another gloss to the left, a2x. -tse is a frequent adjective suffix and the restoration of this second gloss is uncertain (Dieter Maue, p.c.).

a2z. The possibly correct reading tanma[ṣ](ṣa)[r](\) would stand for a 3pl.pt. tanmäṣṣare* with the shorter ending -r (which, as should be noted however, is not in any way regular, not even in the late language ([[Peyrot 2008]]: 133-4) and a for ä in the second syllable. Otherwise, a 3pl.pt.mid. tanmaṣ(ṣa)〈nte〉 would also be a possibility, in view of the fact that this verb is both active and middle ([[Peyrot, ToSu]]: 753).

b1x. For ram 'like' (class. ramt), which normally renders Skt. iva, there is no direct correlate in the Sanskrit text. It is probably a second rendering of vā 'or' in its meaning 'like, as' ([[SWTF]]: IV, 88). Thus, vā was glossed two times: once as wat 'or' and once as ram 'like'. In the second element b1y, tsere is a 3pl.prt.mid.; the Sanskrit equivalent is a 3du.pf.
a1x swaromñ[e]sa a2x /// tse a2y snai miyäṣñe a2z tanma[ṣ]·· b1x lānt wa_t(\) ra_m\ b1y mā ts[e]re /// b2x mā śa[t]ka «†–» papāṣo·e ///

a1x. glosses Skt. Bc.2.8c rasena (instr.sg.) 'in taste'.

a2y. snai miyäṣñe glosses Skt. Bc.2.9c nirāmayaṃ 'free of disease'. A further gloss a2x. ending in ///tse is found to the left, perhaps glossing Skt. Bc.2.9c caiva 'and just' or otherwise the preceding sukhaṃ 'ease' (Dieter Maue, p.c.). a2z. tanmaṣ(ṣar) glosses Skt. Bc.2.9d praj(a)jñ(ire) 'gave birth'. This gloss and the relevant Sanskrit text are flipped over to the verso of the fragment. The last akṣara-like symbol under jñ(i), a little bit to the right, belongs to a gloss to the original text of the verso, not this one (see line b1x lānt wat). The gloss is written in black ink, apparently on an earlier gloss in fainter ink, perhaps originally the same word. The beginning of the gloss is clear and it is certainly a form of tǝnmǝsk-caus. 'generate; give birth', but it is not fully clear whether the last akṣara is completely abraded or has simply been left out. Since there may be a long descender going down to the right of [d]ā in the next line (a3), the correct reading may be tanma[ṣ](ṣa)[r](\).

b1x. lānt wat ram glosses Skt. Bc.2.13c p(a)t(iṃ) v(ā) 'or the lord'. Due to a piece flipped over from the recto, I could not read this gloss fully in my previous study ([[Peyrot 2014]]: 167). The present reading was made possible by a restoration of the fragment. The second element b1y, mā tsere, glosses Skt. Bc.2.13d na vyabhiceratur 'they did not offend; they did not transgress against'. Before the restoration of the fragment, this gloss was not visible at all.

b2x. glosses Skt. Bc.2.14c n(a) cacār(a dharmaṃ) '[none] practised religion' ([[Johnston 1935-1936]]: II, 22). Faint lines under this gloss blur the reading. The akṣara following [t]ka is illegible and seems to have been wiped out intentionally. In my previous study ([[Peyrot 2014]]: 167), I had read mā śa[t]ka – pap[āṣṣ]· /// = mā śatka papāṣṣ(orñe). Thanks to the restoration of the fragment, the reading could be slightly improved. In any case, if the reading is correct (my interpretation requires that the grey spot found here was not intended to be part of the gloss), the gloss appears to be the reverse of the Sanskrit text: in the Sanskrit text, the law is not practised; in the Tocharian gloss, the law is not violated.
